title: High Contrast Serif from FUJI VHS Box
content:
Anyone know this high contrast serif from a FUJI VHS box that reads"HQ HIGH QUALITY TAPE"? Many thanks!

Font: 

 Photo Compressed Font w/ several substitutes 

Solved By: 

 [donshottype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/typophile.com/user/205259 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [image.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/typophile.com/files/image_182.jpg) | 1.75 MB |
author: wmfergs

comments.content:
This one has me stumped. A didone, but the Q is atypical of the style.

Some version of Century that was never digitized?

None of the search engines kicks out a match....

VHS tape boxes. I used to have a huge number of these, including this brand. Looks like a photo compressed font. There are normal width substitutes that might pass for \_HQ\_, such as Century Oldstyle [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/century-os-mt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/century-os-mt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/century-os-mt/") but I didn't spot anything that world work perfectly as a digital substitute for the compressed text \_HQ HIGH QUALITY TAPE\_. The closest I was able to find out of the box is Georg Trump's Mauritius Medium Condensed as digitized by Canada Type

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MauritiusMediumCondensedInUse_3834.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/mauritius/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/mauritius/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/mauritius/")  
An alternative, Monotype Clarendon® Condensed  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MonotypeClarendonCondensedInUse_5727.jpg)
  
 [http://www.fonts.com/font/monotype/monotype-clarendon/condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.fonts.com/font/monotype/monotype-clarendon/condensed "http://www.fonts.com/font/monotype/monotype-clarendon/condensed")  
Don

edited:  
You can get a lot closer by taking a bold weight of a font with similar letterforms and compressing the width to perhaps 85%  
This one is News 706 Bold

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452im_/http:/typophile.com/files/News706BoldInUseWidth85pct_4479.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/news-706/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/news-706/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/news-706/")  
If you want to get a pretty good match you could edit the tail on Q and anything else that you think is out of place.  
A runner up is Harriet Text Bold  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HarrietTextBoldInUseWidth85pct_4342.jpg)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/okay-type/harriet/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/okay-type/harriet/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/okay-type/harriet/") Same comments on editing.  
Some fonts have a weight heavier than bold, which might give a better match for weight when the width is compressed to perhaps 85%  
This one is Ingeborg Heavy.
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452im_/http:/typophile.com/files/IngeborgHeavyInUseWidth85pct_3698.jpg)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/ingeborg/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317080452/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/ingeborg/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/ingeborg/") Same comments on editing.  
Don

Wow, thanks for all the info, Don! I particularly like News 706 Bold and Ingeborg Heavy at 85%. I'll try experimenting with those and the others and, perhaps, drawing it from scratch as an alternative.
